title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V for various functions like managing federal property and regulating financial institutions. It also covers general provisions in Title VII and Cuba sanctions in Title I. Additionally, it funds the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. Financial regulatory agencies are not funded through FSGG appropriations bills. The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies for various functions, excluding financial regulatory agencies. The bill has been in its current form since 2007 and funds agencies in both the House and Senate, with the exception of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC). President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies funded through the FSGG bill, with $330 million allocated for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 3280) on July 18, 2017. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 3280) on July 18, 2017, with funding for FSGG independent agencies totaling $253 million. An additional $248 million for the CFTC was included in the Agriculture appropriations bill. The total funding of $501 million was significantly below the President's FY2018 request. H.R. 3280 was later included as Division D of H.R. 3354, which passed the House on September 14, 2017, with amendments reducing GSA funding and increasing SBA funding. The House passed H.R. 3354 on September 14, 2017, with changes including decreased GSA funding and increased SBA funding. The Senate Committee on Appropriations released a recommended FSGG draft bill on November 20, 2017, with funding totaling $593 million for independent agencies, $2.5 billion below the President's request. Continuing resolutions were enacted to provide funding for FSGG agencies through December 8, 2017, with anomalies focusing on decreasing funding related to the presidential transition. The FSGG anomalies in FY2018 focused on decreasing funding related to the presidential transition. Several continuing resolutions were enacted, with additional funding for the GSA and SBA to address disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 was enacted on March 23, 2018, with legislative language affecting financial regulation included in different divisions. The FSGG appropriations for FY2018 totaled $4.7 billion, with significant differences between requested and enacted amounts for various agencies. The EAC received funding for grants to states for election reform programs. Tables show the status of appropriations measures and amounts requested by the President. The FSGG appropriations bill provides funding for independent agencies overseeing derivatives markets, including the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Their functions include oversight of futures and swaps markets, fraud prevention, and investor protection. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) oversees futures and swaps markets, fraud prevention, and investor protection. The Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction, resulting in oversight of economically significant swaps markets. Congressional authorization jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees due to the market's historical origins in agricultural markets. Appropriations for the CFTC are under the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee in the House and the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Subcommittee in the Senate. The Dodd-Frank Act expanded CFTC jurisdiction to include over-the-counter swaps markets, bringing oversight to swaps markets with an estimated notional value of $240 trillion in the US. The CFTC also oversees futures and options markets with a notional value of $34 trillion. Funding for the CFTC in FY2018 was $249 million. The Consumer Product Safety Commission works to reduce consumer risks from various products through safety standards and recalls. The Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) is responsible for creating safety standards, developing voluntary standards, banning unsafe products, monitoring recalls, educating consumers, conducting research, and collaborating with governments. The Trump Administration requested $123 million for the CPSC in FY2018, with proposed reductions in funding for specific programs and salaries. The CPSC's budget request for FY2018 included allocations for workforce development, product safety prevention, hazard response, and consumer communication. The House passed H.R. 3354 with $123 million for the CPSC, including $1.3 million for new VGBPSA grants. The House Appropriations Committee expects the CPSC to maintain the FY2017 grant funding level and advised against adopting two proposed rules. The committee expects the CPSC to maintain FY2017 grant funding level in FY2018. They advised against adopting two proposed rules, one on voluntary recalls for small firms and the other on public disclosure of product hazards. The bill included two administrative provisions for the CPSC, one barring funds for a rule on recreational off-highway vehicles until a study is completed, and the other prohibiting funds for a rule on injuries from blade saws. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 allocated $126 million and included one administrative provision. The Election Assistance Commission provides grant funding for election reform programs and voting machine testing and certification. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA) to provide grant funding for election reform programs and voting machine testing. The EAC also publishes studies on election issues and sets voluntary guidelines for voting systems standards. The Department of Justice enforces HAVA, and the President's budget request for FY2018 included $9.2 million for the EAC. The EAC received $10.1 million in funding, with $1.5 million transferred to NIST for election reform activities. Additionally, $380 million was appropriated for improving election administration. The FCC, established in 1934, regulates communications and is funded through regulatory fees collected from license holders. The FCC is funded through regulatory fees collected from license holders. For FY2018, the FCC requested a budget of $322 million derived from these fees. The appropriations bill allocated $322 million for the FCC, with an additional $600 million for the TV broadcaster relocation fund. The FDIC is funded through deposit insurance funds outside of the appropriations process. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is funded through deposit insurance funds and received $39.1 million in FY2018. The FEC administers the Federal Election Campaign Act and presidential public financing system. The FEC oversees educational outreach, rulemaking, enforcement, and litigation, as well as issuing advisory opinions and administering the presidential public financing system. For FY2018, the agency requested $71.25 million, with most of the budget allocated to salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. The House and Senate passed bills to provide the requested funding, including an additional $7.9 million for office space relocation. Other sections of the legislation included provisions related to campaign finance policy. The legislation included provisions related to campaign finance policy, such as prohibiting the SEC from issuing rules on disclosure of political contributions, limiting trade associations' solicitation of member-companies' employees, and prohibiting reporting political contributions as a condition of government contracting. The FTC's primary responsibilities are consumer protection and maintaining fair business practices. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) enforces laws to protect consumers and promote competition in various industries. Its funding sources include direct appropriations, premerger filing fees, and Do-Not-Call Registry fees. In FY2017, direct appropriations accounted for 53.3% of the FTC's budget. In FY2018, the FTC's budget breakdown included 53.3% from direct appropriations, 41.8% from HSR filing fees, and 5.0% from DNC registry fees. The President's budget request proposed a total of $306.3 million for the FTC, $6.7 million less than FY2017. The House passed a bill allocating $164.3 million in direct appropriations, $126 million from HSR filing fees, and $16 million from DNC registry fees for the FTC in FY2018. The House Appropriations Committee requested reports on the FTC's enforcement of privacy laws and future plans. The House committee ordered the FTC to report on consumer benefits of credit education services and the impact of the Credit Repair Organizations Act. The Senate draft bill allocated $306.3 million for the FTC, with funding from various sources. The General Services Administration manages federal procurement policies and facilities for former Presidents. The General Services Administration (GSA) oversees federal civilian procurement policies for federal buildings, property disposal, and records management. GSA's real property activities are funded through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF), a revolving fund supported by rental payments from federal agencies leasing GSA space. Congress allocates FBF revenue for specific activities like construction, repairs, rental payments, and building operations. GSA must adhere to limitations set by Congress on FBF funds, and may use the funds to pay certain debts. A negative total for the FBF occurs when available funds are less than expected revenue, but does not mean no funds are available. The Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) supports GSA's real property activities through rental payments. A negative FBF total occurs when available funds are less than expected revenue. GSA's operating accounts are funded separately. The President proposed $9.951 billion for GSA's real property activities in FY2018, an increase from FY2017. The House-passed bill included $7.842 billion, a decrease from the previous year. The President proposed a limit of $9.951 billion from the FBF's available revenue for GSA's real property activities for FY2018, an increase of $1.106 billion above the amount provided in FY2017. The House-passed bill included a limit of $7.842 billion, a decrease of $1.003 billion from FY2017. The Senate draft bill would have provided a limit of $7.809 billion, $1.036 billion less than FY2017. P.L. 115-141 provided a limit of $9.074 billion, an increase of $229 million above FY2017. The President also requested $511 million for GSA's operating accounts, an increase of $257 million above FY2017. The President's request included $40 million for the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund (APSMF) established by the FAST Act. The President's request for FY2018 included appropriations for the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund (APSMF), the Environmental Review Improvement Fund, and the Technology Modernization Fund. The House-passed bill allocated $240 million for GSA's operating accounts, while the Senate draft bill provided $234 million. Both amounts were less than the President's request. The Senate draft bill allocated $234 million for GSA's operating accounts, $20 million less than FY2017 and $277 million less than the President's request. P.L. 115-141 provided $335 million for GSA's operating accounts, $81 million more than FY2017 and $176 million less than the President's request. Additionally, P.L. 115-123 included $127 million in emergency supplemental GSA appropriations. The FSGG appropriations bill funds agencies like FLRA, MSPB, OPM, and OSC. The FLRA is an independent federal agency that administers and enforces Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively. Specific agencies like the FBI, CIA, GAO, NSA, TVA, FLRA, FSIP, and U.S. Secret Service are excluded from the statute. The FLRA is composed of a three-member authority. The FLRA is an independent federal agency that administers and enforces Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively. It resolves disputes over bargaining units, unfair labor practices, and representation elections. The President appoints members to the authority and the FSIP. The FLRA's budget for FY2018 was $26.2 million, funding 121 full-time equivalents. The President requested $26.2 million for the FLRA, funding 121 FTEs. The MSPB requested $46.8 million for FY2018, funding 235 FTEs. The budget for both agencies was approved as requested. The agency's efforts for data center migration and e-Adjudication projects were funded as requested by the President. OPM requested $148.3 million for FY2018, including funds for IT infrastructure modernization and acquisition workforce capacity. The budget requested appropriations for trust fund transfers, OIG salaries, and expenses, and IT modernization. OPM requested an increase in FTE employment levels for FY2018 to address critical IT infrastructure needs and maintain security posture. The OIG will continue oversight through audits, investigations, and evaluations of OPM programs, including the FEHBP and retirement trust fund programs. The OIG will oversee OPM programs, including the prescription drug audit program and IT infrastructure project. Appropriations for OPM include $129.3 million for salaries and expenses, $131.4 million for trust fund transfers, $5 million for OIG salaries and expenses, and up to $25 million for OIG trust fund transfers. H.R. 3354 required a report on OPM's cybersecurity policies and procedures. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees requested a report from OPM within six months of the act's enactment to evaluate cybersecurity measures, oversight of IT contractors, and compliance with government-wide cybersecurity initiatives. Directives included modernizing the federal retirement process and improving information technology security measures. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize security clearance processing, make necessary reforms for expedited investigations, and provide biannual progress reports on the NBIB implementation plan and costs. The OPM OIG must submit a report assessing the implementation within 12 months of the act's enactment. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize security clearance processing, make necessary reforms for expedited investigations, and provide biannual progress reports on the NBIB implementation plan and costs. Additionally, OPM must submit a report assessing the implementation of NBIB, staffing needs, performance issues, costs, governance structure, and recommendations within 12 months of the act's enactment. The committee also emphasized the importance of fulfilling critical OPM functions such as recruitment, retention, and development of the federal workforce. OPM is required to report on a plan to reduce barriers to Federal employment, improve the hiring process, and increase recruitment efforts at various institutions. The House committee directed OPM to improve federal recruitment efforts, especially at Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. OPM was also directed to report on actions taken to enhance the hiring of CyberCorps graduates and improve acquisition planning. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 directed OPM to improve cybersecurity, modernization efforts, and report on the retirement claims backlog. The House committee also instructed OPM to enhance federal recruitment efforts, especially at Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and to improve the hiring of CyberCorps graduates. The House and Senate Committees on Appropriations require monthly progress reports on the retirement claims backlog. Mandatory appropriations for health benefits, life insurance, and retirement accounts were provided in H.R. 3354 and P.L. 115-141. The Congressional Budget Office estimated funding for various government payments. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) requested $26.5 million for FY2018 with an estimated FTE employment level of 144. The OSC's mission is to protect federal employees from prohibited personnel practices. The President's budget requested $26.5 million for the Office of Special Counsel (OSC) in FY2018, with an estimated FTE employment level of 144. The funding was intended to meet rising demand for services, protect whistleblowers, and manage increasing case levels. The House passed an appropriation of $24.7 million, while the Senate and P.L. 115-141 provided the requested amount. The House passed an appropriation of $24.7 million for the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA), which was almost $1.8 million less than the President's request. The Senate draft bill and P.L. 115-141 appropriated the same amount as the President requested. The Administration requested $376 million for NARA for FY2018, over $16 million less than FY2017. H.R. 3354 included $380 million while the Senate draft bill would have appropriated $403 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately appropriated $403.2 million for NARA. The National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) is funded largely by the credit unions it regulates and manages the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) to assist low-income credit unions in providing financial services to low-income communities. The Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) was established in 1979 to assist low-income credit unions in providing financial services to low-income communities. It offers low-interest loans, deposits, and technical assistance grants. The President did not request funding for CDRLF in FY2018, but both the House and Senate proposed $2 million, the same as in FY2017. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent agency responsible for financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics in the executive branch. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent federal agency established in 1978 to regulate financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics in the executive branch. OGE's budget for FY2018 was $16.4 million, which was approved in P.L. 115-141. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch in 2007. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was established in 2004 and reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch in 2007. The board's role is to ensure privacy and civil liberties are considered in laws and policies related to terrorism prevention, review their implementation, and advise the President and executive branch on privacy issues. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) advises the President and executive branch on privacy issues related to terrorism prevention. The President requested $8 million for the PCLOB in FY2018, which was appropriated in P.L. 115-114. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) oversees audits of public companies and is funded through accounting support fees. Amendments in the Dodd-Frank Act established funding for the PCAOB through accounting support fees. Sarbanes-Oxley created a scholarship program funded by PCAOB penalties for accounting students. Section 620 of a Senate draft bill allocated $1 million for scholarships, as specified in P.L. 115-141. The SEC's budget is funded through fees collected from securities exchanges, as mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act. The President's FY2018 request for the SEC was $1.85 billion, with additional funding for a new headquarters lease. H.R. 3354 allocated $1.90 billion for the SEC in FY2018, while the Senate draft bill included $1.85 billion. The SEC's FY2018 budget request was $1.85 billion, with $245 million allocated for a new headquarters lease. H.R. 3354 proposed $1.90 billion for the SEC, while the Senate draft bill included $1.85 billion. The Dodd-Frank Act established a reserve fund for the SEC, funded by registration fees, with limits on collections and excess funds going to the Treasury. In FY2017, $25 million was rescinded from the reserve fund, and for FY2018, the President's request and H.R. 3354 proposed rescinding $25 million and $75 million respectively, while the Senate draft bill did not include any rescissions. The House proposed rescinding $75 million from the SEC fund, while the Senate draft bill did not include any rescissions. The Selective Service System is an independent agency for emergency military manpower needs, requiring males aged 18-25 to register. The draft ended in 1973, but in 1980, Congress approved funds for male-only registration. Women can now serve in combat units. The Selective Service System draft ended in 1973 and has not been renewed. President Carter proposed standby draft registration for both men and women in 1980, with funds approved for male-only registration. Women can now serve in combat units, potentially leading to their inclusion in registration. Funding for the SSS has remained stable in absolute dollars but decreased in inflation-adjusted terms. The President's FY2018 budget and legislative drafts all allocated $22.9 million, consistent with FY2017. The Small Business Administration supports small businesses through loan guarantees, low-interest loans for disaster victims, training programs, and advocacy within the federal government. The Small Business Administration (SBA) provides assistance to small businesses, nonprofits, and households affected by disasters and terrorism. The President requested $829.1 million for the SBA in FY2018, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loans, disaster assistance, and other programs. Authorization levels were also requested for various loan guaranty programs. The House-passed bill appropriated $862.8 million for the SBA in FY2018, $33.7 million more than the Administration's request. The bill allocated $260.0 million for salaries and expenses, $231.1 million for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs, and included provisions for Microloan intermediaries to increase spending on technical assistance. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $886.3 million for the SBA, $57.1 million more than the Administration's request. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $886.3 million for the SBA in FY2018, allocating $269.5 million for salaries and expenses and $245.1 million for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs. The final appropriation in P.L. 115-141 was $700.8 million, with no funding for disaster assistance as additional funds were provided in P.L. 115-123 for hurricane costs. The SBA was authorized to use $618.0 million of the supplemental funding for disaster assistance administrative costs. In FY2018, funding of $1.66 billion was allocated to the SBA to address disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The SBA was authorized to use $618.0 million for disaster assistance administrative costs. The USPS generates funding through mail charges, with Congress providing appropriations for revenue forgone for free mailing privileges. Congress authorized appropriations in the 1993 RFRA, including a $29 million annual reimbursement to USPS until 2035 for lost revenue during the RFRA phase-in period. The Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act (PAEA) enacted in 2006 affected postal appropriations process in FY2009. Under PAEA, USPSOIG and PRC must submit budget requests to Congress and OMB. Funding for these agencies comes from the Postal Service Fund. In FY2018, the President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund, $23.4 million more than before. In FY2018, the President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund, an increase of $23.4 million from the previous year. The budget submission also included a request of $71.3 million for USPS, $36.7 million more than its FY2017 appropriation. The President requested $234.7 million for USPSOIG, $19 million less than its FY2017 appropriation, with a request of $275.2 million for FY2018. The House-passed bill would have provided $234.7 million for USPSOIG. The President submitted the USPSOIG's budget request to Congress for FY2018, requesting $275.2 million, an increase of $21.6 million from FY2017. The House-passed bill proposed $234.7 million, while the Senate draft bill suggested $245 million. P.L. 115-141 allocated $245 million. The PRC and the President requested $14.4 million for FY2018, slightly less than the PRC's FY2017 appropriation. H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill would have provided $15.2 million for the PRC, with P.L. 115-141 also allocating $15.2 million. The House-passed bill included various postal policy provisions, such as maintaining six-day mail delivery and providing free mail services for overseas voting and the blind. The House committee report directed the Postmaster General to increase sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The Trump Administration proposed cost-reducing reforms for USPS, including adjusting mail delivery frequency and rate structure. The Trump Administration proposed cost-reducing reforms for USPS, including adjusting the rate structure to ensure stability and meet statutory obligations for retiree benefits. The President's FY2018 budget stated that these reforms would reduce the budget deficit by $46 billion over 10 years. P.L. 115-141 included policy provisions from the House-passed bill but did not enact further reforms requested by the President. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over tax matters. The United States Tax Court (USTC) did not receive the requested funding in FY2018. The court, headquartered in Washington, DC, has jurisdiction over tax matters and conducts trials nationwide. The President's proposed budget of $53.2 million was not enacted, with only $50.7 million appropriated in P.L. 115-141. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes general provisions, some of which were proposed but not enacted for FY2018. The Administration's proposed government-wide general provisions for FY2018 were not made permanent. New provisions included adjusting discretionary spending limits if new budget authority exceeded limits, allowing DACA recipients to be eligible for federal government employment, and OFAC administering Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control. The DACA program recipients would be eligible for federal government employment. The Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control administers Cuba embargo regulations, which have been amended over the years. H.R. 3280 had provisions to tighten U.S. sanctions on Cuba but were not included in the final bill. Section 130 aimed to prohibit the importation of Cuban government-confiscated property, potentially affecting rum and tobacco imports by U.S. travelers. In the 114th Congress, a provision in the House Appropriations Committee version of the FY2017 FSGG appropriations bill aimed to restrict funds for authorizing trademarks related to confiscated Cuban assets. This included a dispute over the Havana Club trademark between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited. OFAC issued a specific license for the Cuban company to renew the trademark, which was subsequently renewed by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office until 2026. In January 2016, OFAC issued a specific license for the Cuban company to make payments for the renewal of the Havana Club trademark, which was subsequently renewed by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office until 2026.
